Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: MAKER: bioMAKERlab: A Wetlab and Starter Activities for Promoting Synthetic Biology in High School Classes and Workshops

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will make synthetic biology activities accessible to high school students and teachers by providing them with an authentic but safe context to learn and broaden their understanding and perspectives of the role of synthetic biology in bioengineering in personal, health, and food production contexts as well as raise their interest in STEM. The design of bioMAKERlab will generate an educational version of an existing professional-grade lab for synthetic biology to promote safe production, accessibility, and affordability for high schools and community colleges interested in integrating such wetlab activities into their curriculum.

Most current efforts to broaden access to maker activities for K-12 students have focused on developing collaborative fabrication workspaces (fablabs) involving 3D printers, laser cutters, and other digital and traditional tools. This project will develop and implement bioMAKERlab, an innovative wetlab starter kit and activities that will enable high school students and teachers to engage in synthetic biology by building genetic circuits that let microorganisms change color, smell, and shape. In synthetic biology, participants make their own DNA--gene by gene--and then grow their designs into real applications by inserting them into microorganisms to develop different traits and characteristics provided by the genes. The project will involve students from a Philadelphia public high school and young people participating in weekend workshops at The Franklin Institute, a Philadelphia-based science museum.

This project is a part of NSF's Maker Dear Colleague Letter portfolio (NSF 15-086), a collaborative investment of Directorates for Computer & Information Science & Engineering, Education and Human Resources, and Engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant focused on developing and implementing equipment and curriculum activities to introduce synthetic biology activities to middle and high school students. Our approach centered on various design activities (e.g., making color changing logotypes, building sensors to detect contaminants, or baking enriched cakes with nutrient producing yeast) whereby students could design, grow and discuss the outcomes of their work with a broader awareness towards the social, cultural, ethical, and environmental impact of these biotechnologies. 

We pursued an iterative approach to the development of wet lab hardware, software and consumables to make them less costly and more usable. Following, we tested them with students and educators with very little or no background expertise in biology. We designed and documented students? experiences and reflections working with biomakerlab wet lab and curriculum activities. Findings revealed that while students know very little about synthetic biology applications that involve the production of non-living outputs such as textiles and manufacturing materials, they have very well formed attitudes toward the field. Furthermore, students make considerations that evaluated risks, benefits, usefulness and moral acceptability of synthetic biology and its various applications?aspects previously observed in older student groups. 

The low-cost portable wet lab has been retrofitted from a commercial egg incubator that can be assembled for under $250 with non-expert knowledge of electronics, coding, and fabrication. We also curated a shopping list of components that can be assembled using basic tools available in mpst school or informal learning spaces. 

The curriculum materials for the biomakerlab include three starter wet lab activities that each illustrate a practical application of synthetic biology. Most importantly they all involve the production of outcomes that are tangible and apparent to students such as color pigments, sensors, or baked goods. Furthermore, they appropriately abstract fundamental concepts in molecular biology and genetics for a K-12 school audience that can be further developed in future learning modules.

In terms of dissemination, we have presented our design and findings at various conferences such as FABLEARN 19, AERA 2019, and CSCL 2019. Furthermore, we shared the building specifications for the biomakerlab and the curriculum activities for three different wet lab activities with the biomakerlab at https://biomakerlab.github.io/ via Creative Commons Licence 4.0.
